questions.question:
Question 1: Which of the following is the most common tumor associated with growth hormone 
deficiency in children?
questions.explanation:
The most common tumor associated with growth hormone (GH) deficiency in children is 
craniopharyngioma. Growth hormone deficiency can be caused by congenital CNS malformations, genetic defects or 
acquired neurological insults. Note: • Most common cause of GH deficiency: Idiopathic • Most common infection causing GH deficiency in India: Tuberculosis > Histoplasmosis • Most common infiltration causing GH deficiency in India: Histiocytosis > Sarcoidosis. • Trophic hormone failure with pituitary compression or destruction: GH> FSH> LH> 
TSH> ACTH. • Most common tumors associated with central diabetes insipidus: Pinealomas, Germinomas 621 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 2: Asha was being bullied about her height in school. The concerned parents bring her to the 
pediatrician who plots the growth chart as shown below. On evaluation, growth hormone 
levels are found to be high and insulin-like growth factor levels are low. Which among the 
following could be a cause?
questions.explanation:
The presence of high GH levels and low insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1) levels point 
towards Laron syndrome/dwarfism. It is caused by end-organ resistance to growth hormone(GH 
insensitivity) due to the GH receptor mutation. It is an autosomal-recessive disorder with clinical 
features as those seen in pituitary dwarfism. Here, growth hormone is produced but is unable to act on the target tissues. Thus, the resting and 
stimulated GH levels are high and IGF-1 levels are low. In Turner's syndrome (Option A), loss of the short arm of the X chromosome is implicated in 
dwarfism. The short stature occurs due to a state of GH resistance, relative deficiency, and 
decreased utilization. Pituitary dwarfism (Option B) is a condition with GH deficiency. Maternal deprivation dwarfism (Option D) is due to psychosocial causes such as emotional 
deprivation and neglect. There is an inadequate response to GH stimulation tests. The mechanism 
is not fully understood. No history suggestive of disturbed maternal or family relationships rules 
this out.

questions.question:
Question 3: Which of the following is the most common genetic cause for multiple pituitary hormone 
deficiency?
questions.explanation:
The most common genetic cause for multiple pituitary hormone deficiencies 
(MPHD)/panhypopituitarism is the mutation of the PROP1 gene. LHX3 and GLI2 are other genes involved in MPHD. GNAS1 mutations cause McCune Albright Syndrome. c-MYC gene is mutated in Burkitt's lymphoma WT-1 gene is mutated in Wilms tumors.

questions.question:
Question 4: You come across a child with growth hormone deficiency during your ward rounds. Which of 
the following features would you not expect in this child?

options.a: History of short stature at birth

questions.explanation:
Children with growth hormone deficiency usually have normal growth at birth. Growth 
retardation (decline in growth velocity) becomes apparent around 1 year of age. Growth in-utero is dependant on genetic, environmental, nutrition and growth factors. GH levels 
peak at mid-gestation, increase at birth, and then reduce by 2 weeks of life. At around 6 months of 
age, GH levels reach pre-pubertal levels and from there on have a major influence on 
growth. Thus the deficiency becomes apparent after a significant period of GH-dependent growth 
has occurred. Characteristic features of growth hormone deficiency (Pituitary Dwarfism): • Normal growth at birth with growth retardation becoming apparent around 1 year of age • Proportionate short stature • Hypoglycemic seizures in newborn 622 
Sold by @itachibot • Small larynx with a high-pitched voice • Small genitalia (micropenis) • Delayed skeletal maturation • Delayed dentition • Delayed puberty (sexual infantilism) • Doll-like facial appearance: small, round facies, frontal prominence, depressed nasal bridge 
(saddle nose), eyes may bulge, underdeveloped mandible and chin, normal head circumference 
but craniofacial disproportion due to small facies • Short neck • Normal intelligence.

questions.question:
Question 5: You are evaluating children with short stature on whether they are eligible to receive growth 
hormone therapy as per FDA guidelines. In which of the following children would you 
prescribe it?

options.a: An 8 year old with Laron dwarfism
options.b: A neonate diagnosed with congenital hypothyroidism
options.c: A 7 year old with Chronic kidney disease
options.d: A 6 year old diagnosed with Maternal deprivation dwarfism

questions.explanation:
Chronic kidney disease is an FDA-approved indication for growth hormone (GH) therapy. Renal failure is a state of GH resistance. Moderate-to-severe growth retardation in chronic kidney 
disease is associated with increased morbidity and mortality. GH therapy with recombinant 
growth hormone has been shown to improve catch-up growth and to allow the child to achieve 
normal adult height; the final adult height is still significantly below the genetic target. FDA-approved indications for growth hormone (GH) treatment- • GH deficiency • Turner's Syndrome • Chronic Renal Failure before Transplantation • Small for Gestational Age / Short Stature • Idiopathic Short Stature • Noonan Syndrome • Prader-Willi Syndrome • AIDS-related wasting • Malabsorption associated with the short-bowel syndrome

questions.question:
Question 6: Chotu, a 5-year-old boy is on regular outpatient follow-up for growth hormone deficiency 
diagnosed 2 weeks back. He is planned for recombinant growth hormone therapy. All of the 
following are possible side effects except-
questions.explanation:
The use of recombinant growth hormone is associated with the risk of type 2 diabetes 
mellitus (not type 1 diabetes mellitus). Other adverse effects: • Pseudotumor cerebri • Slipped capital femoral epiphysis 623 
Sold by @itachibot • Gynecomastia • Worsening of scoliosis Children who have been treated with rhGH have a higher risk of developing hemorrhagic strokes 
in adulthood. Some studies show an increased risk of new neoplasms in cancer survivors.

Question 9: "Weak giants" are produced by

questions.explanation:
624 
Sold by @itachibot "Weak giants" are due to hyperpituitarism that is most commonly produced by pituitary 
adenomas. Hyperpituitarism causes growth hormone (GH) excess, leading to tall stature (giants) with weak 
muscles. Overproduction of GH results in gigantism in children (before fusion of bone growth 
plate) and acromegaly in adults. Clinical features include: • Gigantism, prognathism (protrusion of jaw), hypertrophy of frontal bones • Proximal myopathy (though there is muscle hypertrophy, it is weakened due to atrophy of type II 
muscle fibers) • Acral enlargement in hands and feet (due to thickening of soft tissues) • Visceromegaly: Enlargement of most organs especially the tongue, thyroid, salivary gland, liver, 
spleen, kidney, and prostate • Local effects of the adenoma: Headache, visual field defects, raised ICT Note: Although hypothalamic hamartomas can also produce gigantism, the most common cause 
of gigantism is pituitary adenomas.

questions.question:
Question 10: A young boy is diagnosed to have central diabetes insipidus. A lesion in which of the following 
nuclei is likely to cause this condition?
questions.explanation:
Lesions in the supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus can cause central 
diabetes insipidus. These nuclei synthesize vasopressin, a 9-amino-acid peptide with antidiuretic and vascular 
pressor activity. It is transported to the posterior pituitary via axonal projections, where it is 
stored for release into the systemic circulation. Diabetes insipidus (DI) is characterized by pathologic polyuria and polydipsia (>2 L/m²/24 hr or 
5 mL/kg/hr). It can result from either: • Vasopressin deficiency (decreased anti-diuretic hormone production) causes central DI. • Vasopressin insensitivity at the level of the kidney causes nephrogenic DI.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 4-year-old boy was brought by his mother with new-onset nocturnal bedwetting. She also 
reported, he has been drinking more water for the last 3-4 months. 24-hour urine volume was 
4 liters and the urine osmolality was low. ADH assays recorded a value was 0.7 pg/mL. T1 
weighted MRI brain indicated an absence of a pituitary bright spot. What is the treatment of 
choice for his condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of central diabetes insipidus. The treatment of choice 
is desmopressin. It is a vasopressin analog (V2 receptor agonist). It can be administered 
intranasally, or subcutaneously. Option A: Leuprolide is a GnRH (gonadotropin-releasing hormone) analog used in the treatment 
of prostate cancer, breast cancer, and endometriosis. Option B: Thiazides paradoxically exert an antidiuretic effect in DI but are not the drug of choice. 
They are generally used in nephrogenic DI. 625 
Sold by @itachibot Option D: Terlipressin is a long-acting analog on vasopressin that acts on V1 receptors of vascular 
smooth muscle. It is used as a vasopressor in shock and acute variceal bleeding.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 6-year-old boy diagnosed with Wolfram syndrome is admitted to the pediatric ward of your 
hospital. Which of the following features would you expect to find in this child?
questions.explanation:
Optic Atrophy is seen in Wolfram syndrome. The components of the syndrome are represented by 
the acronym DIDMOAD: • Diabetes Insipidus • Diabetes Mellitus (type 1) • Optic Atrophy • Neural Deafness It is caused by mutations of the WFS1 gene.

questions.question:
Question 13: While working in a tertiary care center, a 5-year-old girl presents with polyuria, polydipsia, 
and nocturnal enuresis for the past 1 year. A water deprivation test is done and shows low 
urine osmolality on stopping the intake of water. On desmopressin administration, there is a 
7% rise in urine osmolality. The treatment of this condition uses all of the following except?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. The treatment includes 
pharmacological treatment combined with salt restriction and not increased salt intake. Treatment of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus: • Adequate water intake along with a low sodium diet • Thiazide diuretics: Acts by • Volume contraction and increases the responsiveness of other parts of the tubule • Increase the AQP2 channels independent of vasopressin • Potassium-sparing diuretics (triamterene and amiloride): Amiloride is the drug of choice for 
lithium-induced DI • Prostaglandin synthesis inhibitor (indomethacin) 626
